1.question: What are the three main groups of Aboriginal peoples?

2.question: Who was John Buchan?
options: A popular Governor General of Canada
One of the Fathers of Confederation
2.answer: A popular Governor General of Canada

3.question: When did the House of Commons recognize that the Quebecois form a nation within a united Canada?

4.question: Who is Marjorie Turner-Bailey?
options: An Olympian and descendant of black Loyalists
The first woman to become Prime Minister
4.answer: An Olympian and descendant of black Loyalists

5.question: When did English settlement begin in Canada?

6.question: Who established the first European settlements?

7.question: Who passed the Quebec Act of 1774?

8.question: Which Act granted to the Canadas, for the first time, legislative assemblies elected by the people?

9.question: Who was Lieutenant Colonel John Graves Simcoe?
options: Upper Canada's first Lieutenant Governor and founder of the City of Toronto
Lower Canada's first Lieutenant Governor and founder of the City of Toronto
Lower Canada's first Lieutenant Governor and founder of the City of Ottawa
9.answer: Upper Canada's first Lieutenant Governor and founder of the City of Toronto

10.question: When did the British Parliament abolish slavery throughout the Empire?

11.question: Name 3 fathers of Confederation
options: Sir Étienne-Paschal Taché, Sir George-Étienne Cartier, and Sir John A. Macdonald
La Fontaine, Robert Baldwin, and Joseph Howe
Joseph Brant, Joseph Howe, and James Macdonald
Jospeh Howe, Robert La Fontaine, and Sir Étienne-Paschal Taché
11.answer: Sir Étienne-Paschal Taché, Sir George-Étienne Cartier, and Sir John A. Macdonald

12.question: Which phrase embodied the vision for the Dominion of Canada?
options: Oh Canada, my home and native land
Dominion from sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth
The land of the free and strong
12.answer: Dominion from sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth

13.question: Whose portrait is on the Canadian $10 bill?

14.question: What made it possible for immigrants to settle in Western Canada?
options: The completion of the port of Vancouver
The completion of the Canadian National Railway
The giving of free land to new settlers
The completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway
14.answer: The completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway

15.question: When were the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans devised?

16.question: What is "La Francophonie"?
options: An international association of French-speaking countries
16.answer: An international association of French-speaking countries

17.question: Why is Terry Fox a Canadian national hero?
options: He inspired people to contribute money for cancer research
He became the first elected President of Canada
He was the greatest hockey player of all time
He united Canada in the 19th century
17.answer: He inspired people to contribute money for cancer research

18.question: What are the responsibilities of the federal government?
options: Matters of national and international concern
18.answer: Matters of national and international concern

19.question: Who has the right to vote in a federal election?
options: A Canadian citizen, at least 18 years old on voting day and on the voters' list
Adult Canadian citizens and permanent residents
Canadian citizens on the voters' list
19.answer: A Canadian citizen, at least 18 years old on voting day and on the voters' list

20.question: Where do the majority of Canadians live?

21.question: The Constitution of Canada was amended to entrench which Canadian Charter in 1982?
options: Canadian Charter of Right and Freedom
Canadian Charter of Crime and Punishment
21.note: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982 to entrench the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

22.question: Which one of the following is not a source of the Law present in Canada?
22.note: Canadian law has several sources, including laws passed by Parliament and the provincial legislatures, English common law, the civil code of France and the unwritten constitution that we have inherited from Great Britain.

23.question: Through Habeas Corpus, a person can challenge unlawful detention by the state. It is derived from which Law?
23.note: Habeas corpus, the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state, comes from English common law.

24.question: “Whereas Canada is founded upon principles that recognize the supremacy of God and the Rule of Law”. This phrase underlines the importance of
options: Dignity and Worth of Human Person
24.note: Whereas Canada is founded upon principles that recognize the supremacy of God and the rule of law.” This phrase indicates the importance of religious as well as moral values and traditions to Canadian society and the dignity and worth of the human person.

25.question: How old is the tradition of ordered liberty that Canada contains?
25.note: Canada contains an 800 years old tradition of ordered liberty, which dates back to the signing of Magna Carta in 1215 in England (also known as the Great Charter of Freedoms).

26.question: Together with Canadian law that was inherited from the past, Canada also has an 800 years old tradition of ordered liberty, which dates back to the signing of
26.note: Canadian law has several sources, including laws passed by Parliament and the provincial legislatures, English common law, the civil code of France, and the unwritten constitution that we have inherited from Great Britain. Together, these secure for Canadians an 800year old tradition of ordered liberty, which dates back to the signing of Magna Carta in 1215 in England (also known as the Great Charter of Freedoms).

27.question: According to law, which of the following gives a person the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state and imprisonment
27.note: Habeas corpus, the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state, comes from English common law.

28.question: Who is Canada’s representative?
28.note: Canada is personified by The sovereign.

29.question: The Constitution of Canada was amended in which year?
29.note: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982.

30.question: Immigrants between the ages of 18 and 54 must have adequate knowledge of
30.note: Those willing to become the part Canadian Culture, between the ages of 18 and 54 must have adequate knowledge of French and English.

31.question: Who are regulated by the Laws in Canada?
31.note: One of Canada’s founding principles is the rule of law. Individuals and governments are regulated by laws and not by arbitrary actions.

32.question: To become a part of Canada, what is the age limit for a person that must have adequate knowledge of French and English?
32.note: Those willing for Canadian Citizenship, between the ages of 18 and 54 must have adequate knowledge of French and English.

33.question: Under Oath of Citizenship in Canada, To which person do the Canadian Citizens swear Allegiance?
33.note: In the Canadian Oath of Citizenship, we swear allegiance to the Sovereign.

34.question: A Member of Parliament from Montreal announces that she will spend her weekend in her electoral district. This means she would be:
options: In her office on Parliament Hill.
In the part of Montreal where she was elected.
34.answer: In the part of Montreal where she was elected.

35.question: After a federal election, which party forms the new government?
options: The party with the most elected representatives is invited by the Governor General to become the party in power.
The King himself picks any party to run the government.
The Governor General proposes a law for elected officials to become the governing body.
The Premiers of each province pick a party to run the government
35.answer: The party with the most elected representatives is invited by the Governor General to become the party in power.

36.question: Approximately how many Canadians served in the First World War?

37.question: Canada has three territories and how many provinces?

38.question: Fatima is a new immigrant in Canada.  What law allows her to take a job at par with a man?

39.question: From where does the name “Canada” come from?
options: From the Inuit word meaning country.
From the French word meaning joining.
From the Métis word meaning rivers.
From "Kanata", the Huron-Iroquois word for village.
39.answer: From "Kanata", the Huron-Iroquois word for village.

40.question: Give an example of how you can show responsibility by participating in your community.

41.question: Give an example of where English and French have equal status in Canada.

42.question: Give the first line of Canada’s national anthem?
options: O Canada!  Our home and native land!
O Canada!  Our province and native land!
O Canada!  From far and wide, O Canada,
O Canada!  We stand on guard for thee.
42.answer: O Canada!  Our home and native land!

43.question: How are Members of Parliament chosen?

44.question: How are Senators chosen?
options: By the Governor General of Canada.
By the Premiers of all provinces.
Senators are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister.
44.answer: Senators are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister.

45.question: How does a bill become a law?
options: The Lieutenant Governor must approve the bill.
Approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and finally the Governor General.
The King must sign the bill.
Approval by the Members of the Legislative Assembly.
45.answer: Approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and finally the Governor General.

46.question: How is a Cabinet Minister chosen?

47.question: How is the government formed after a federal election?
options: The party with the most elected representatives becomes the party in power. The King chooses the Prime Minister from this party
Ordinarily, the party with the most elected representatives becomes the party in power. The leader of this party becomes the Prime Minister.
The Governor General picks a party and a Prime Minister to run the government.
Each province elects one representative to form the government. The King then chooses the Prime Minister.
47.answer: Ordinarily, the party with the most elected representatives becomes the party in power. The leader of this party becomes the Prime Minister.

48.question: How is the Prime Minister chosen?
options: The King appoints the Prime Minister.
The Governor General with the Senate appoint the Prime Minister.
The leader of the party with the most elected representatives becomes the Prime Minister.
The MPs vote on the Prime Minister.
48.answer: The leader of the party with the most elected representatives becomes the Prime Minister.

49.question: In Canada, are you allowed to question the police about their service or conduct?
options: No, police service and conduct is not open to discussion with Canadians.
Yes, you can question their service but not their conduct.
Yes, you can question their conduct but not their service.
Yes, if you feel the need to.
49.answer: Yes, if you feel the need to.

50.question: In Canada’s justice system what does “presumption of innocence” mean?
options: Everyone is guilty until proven innocent
Guilt is decided by public opinion
Innocence is decided by public opinion
Everyone is innocent until proven guilty
50.answer: Everyone is innocent until proven guilty

51.question: In the 1960s, Quebec experienced an era of rapid change. What is this called?

52.question: In what industry do most Canadians work?

53.question: In which region do more than half the people in Canada live?

54.question: Name all the federal political parties in the House of Commons and their leaders
options: Conservative (Poilievre), NDP (Singh), Liberal (Trudeau), Bloc Quebecois (Blanchet), Green Party (May)
54.answer: Conservative (Poilievre), NDP (Singh), Liberal (Trudeau), Bloc Quebecois (Blanchet), Green Party (May)

55.question: Name six responsibilities of citizenship.
options: Getting a job, making money, raising a family, paying taxes, mowing your lawn, voting in provincial elections.
Voting in municipal elections only, joining a political party, getting a job, obeying the law, driving safely, picking up litter.
Caring for the environment, not littering, paying taxes, obeying the law, helping others, respecting others.
Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and one's family, helping others in the community, voting in elections, serving on a jury, protecting and enjoying our heritage and environment.
55.answer: Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and one's family, helping others in the community, voting in elections, serving on a jury, protecting and enjoying our heritage and environment.

56.question: Name the five regions of Canada
options: Maritimes, Ontario, Quebec, Prairies, and British Columbia
Atlantic, Central, Prairie, West Coast, and North
West, Central, East, Prairies, and Territories
56.answer: Atlantic, Central, Prairie, West Coast, and North

57.question: Name three additional rights protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
options: Freedom of speech, Right to own land, and Right to a fair trial.
Mobility rights, Multiculturalism, and Aboriginal Peoples' rights.
Right to ski anywhere in Canada, Moving rights, and Right to public assembly.
Right to vote, Right to speak publicly, and Security rights.
57.answer: Mobility rights, Multiculturalism, and Aboriginal Peoples' rights.

58.question: Name two fundamental freedoms protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
options: Freedom of conscience and religion, and Freedom of association.
Equality rights, and to care for Canada's heritage.
Aboriginal peoples' rights, and to volunteer.
58.answer: Freedom of conscience and religion, and Freedom of association.

59.question: Name two key documents that contain our rights and freedoms.
options: The Canadian Constitution and English common law.
Civil code of France and the Canadian Constitution.
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and Magna Carta (the Great Charter of Freedoms).
Laws passed by Parliament and English common law.
59.answer: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and Magna Carta (the Great Charter of Freedoms).

60.question: Name two responsibilities of the federal government.

61.question: Name two responsibilities of the provincial and territorial government.

62.question: On what date did Nunavut become a territory?

63.question: One third of all Canadians live in which province?

64.question: The Canadian Coat of Arms and motto is “A Mari Usque Ad Mare.”  This means:
options: From the ocean to the sea.
From the sea to the ends of the earth.
From the water to the earth.

65.question: What are some examples of taking responsibility for yourself and your family?
options: Buying a house and a TV.
Getting a job, taking care of one's family and working hard in keeping with one's abilities.
Doing laundry and keeping the house clean.
Study hard so you can earn enough money to take a vacation.
65.answer: Getting a job, taking care of one's family and working hard in keeping with one's abilities.

66.question: What are the Prairie provinces and their capital cities?

67.question: What are the provinces of Central Canada and their capital cities?
options: Quebec (Quebec City) and Prince Edward Island (Charlottetown).

68.question: What are the provinces of the Atlantic region and their capital cities?
options: Nova Scotia (Halifax), New Brunswick (Fredericton), Prince Edward Island (Charlottetown) and Quebec (Quebec).
Newfoundland and Labrador (St. John's), Nova Scotia (Halifax), New Brunswick (Fredericton) and Prince Edward Island (Charlottetown).
Newfoundland and Labrador (St. John's), Nova Scotia (Halifax), New Brunswick (Fredericton) and Quebec (Quebec).
Nova Scotia (Halifax), New Brunswick (Fredericton), Quebec (Quebec City)and Ontario (Toronto).
68.answer: Newfoundland and Labrador (St. John's), Nova Scotia (Halifax), New Brunswick (Fredericton) and Prince Edward Island (Charlottetown).

69.question: What are the territories of Northern Canada and their capital cities?
options: Yukon Territory (Whitehorse), Northwest Territories (Yellowknife), and Nunavut (Iqaluit).
69.answer: Yukon Territory (Whitehorse), Northwest Territories (Yellowknife), and Nunavut (Iqaluit).

70.question: What are the three levels of government in Canada?

71.question: What are the three main groups of Aboriginal peoples?
options: United Empire Loyalists, Métis and Inuit.

72.question: What are the three main types of industry in Canada?
options: Natural resources, tourism and service industries..

73.question: What are the three parts of Parliament?
options: The Sovereign, Governor General and Prime Minister.
The House of Commons, the Legislative Assembly and the Senate.
The King, the Legislative Assembly and the Senate.
The Sovereign, the House of Commons and the Senate.
73.answer: The Sovereign, the House of Commons and the Senate.

74.question: What are the two official languages of Canada?

75.question: What country is Canada’s largest trading partner?

76.question: What did the Canadian Pacific Railway symbolize?
options: Easy access to the West Coast.
What can be achieved by working together.

77.question: What did the Fathers of Confederation do?
options: They worked together to establish a new country, the Dominion of Canada
They were explorers who formed an expedition to survey Northern Canada
They formed a republic state in Canada
They were a group of politicians that tried to unite Canada to the United States
77.answer: They worked together to establish a new country, the Dominion of Canada

78.question: What do you call a law before it is passed?

79.question: What do you call the Sovereign’s representative in the provinces?

80.question: What do you mark on a federal election ballot?

81.question: What does Confederation mean?
options: The United States Confederate soldiers came to Canada.
Joining of communities to become a province.
Joining of suburbs to form a large city.
Joining of provinces to make a new country.
81.answer: Joining of provinces to make a new country.

82.question: What does it mean to say Canada is a constitutional monarchy?
options: The Sovereign (Queen or King) is the law maker of Canada.
Canada's Head of State is a hereditary Sovereign (Queen or King) who reigns in accordance with the Constitution.
The Sovereign (Queen or King) represents Canadians in Parliament.
The Sovereign (Queen or King) approves bills before becoming law.
82.answer: Canada's Head of State is a hereditary Sovereign (Queen or King) who reigns in accordance with the Constitution.

83.question: What does the “right to a secret ballot” mean?
options: No one should tell you where to vote
A secret vote used by politicians when they are voting on sensitive topics
No one can watch your vote and no one should look at how you voted
Your right to vote in secret on who to appoint to the Senate
83.answer: No one can watch your vote and no one should look at how you voted

84.question: What does the Canadian flag look like?
options: Red and white with provincial emblems.
Red and white with a beaver.
White with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre.
Red with a white maple leaf.
84.answer: White with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre.

85.question: What does the term “responsible government” mean?
options: Each person in each electoral district is responsible for voting.
The Governor General is responsible for the actions of the Prime Minister.
The ministers of the Crown must have the support of a majority of the elected representatives in order to govern.
All Canadians are responsible for each other.
85.answer: The ministers of the Crown must have the support of a majority of the elected representatives in order to govern.

87.question: What happened at the Battle of the Plains of Abraham?
options: The Voyagers battled with the British for fur trading rights
Americans fought the United Empire Loyalists during the American Revolution
The British defeated the French marking the end of France's empire in America
The French defeated the British in a battle for Quebec
87.answer: The British defeated the French marking the end of France's empire in America

88.question: What is a Francophone?
options: A person who speaks English as their first language
A smartphone designed by the Canadian company RIM
A person who speaks French as their first language
The first phone in Canada, invented by Alexander Graham Bell
88.answer: A person who speaks French as their first language

89.question: What is a major river in Quebec?

90.question: What is a majority government?
options: When the party in power holds about one third of the seats in the House of Commons
When the party in power holds about one quarter of the seats in the House of Commons.
When the part in power holds at least half of the seats in the Senate.
When the party in power holds at least half of the seats in the House of Commons.
90.answer: When the party in power holds at least half of the seats in the House of Commons.

91.question: What is a voter information card?
options: Tells you who the candidates are in your electoral district.
Tells you what province to vote in.
A form that tells you when and where to vote.
A form that lets you know your voting time.
91.answer: A form that tells you when and where to vote.

92.question: What is Canada’s national winter sport?

93.question: What is Canada’s system of government called?

94.question: What is meant by the equality of women and men?
options: Men and women are equal under the law.
Men and women must both do housework.
Women may now go to school and enter the professional workforce.
A woman may now become Prime Minister.
94.answer: Men and women are equal under the law.

95.question: What is the “head tax”?
options: Race-based entry fee charged for Chinese entering Canada.
Fee charged for anyone entering Canada after 1900.
A tax imposed on beer beginning in 1867.
Fee charged for moving westward in the early 1900s.
95.answer: Race-based entry fee charged for Chinese entering Canada.

96.question: What is the capital city of Canada?

97.question: What is the difference between the role of the Sovereign and that of the Prime Minister?
options: The Sovereign is Head of State, the Prime Minister oversees provincial policies.
The Sovereign is the guardian of Constitutional freedoms, the Prime Minister selects the Cabinet ministers and is responsible for operations and policy of government.
The Sovereign links Canada to 52 other nations and the Prime Minister is the guardian of Constitutional freedoms.
The Sovereign is the symbol of Canadian sovereignty and the Prime Minister is her aide.
97.answer: The Sovereign is the guardian of Constitutional freedoms, the Prime Minister selects the Cabinet ministers and is responsible for operations and policy of government.

98.question: What is the government of all of Canada called?

99.question: What is the highest court in Canada?

100.question: What is the highest military honour a Canadian can receive?

101.question: What is the largest religious affiliation in Canada?

102.question: What is the meaning of the Remembrance Day poppy?
options: To remember our Sovereign, Queen Elizabeth II.
To honour Prime Ministers who have died.
To remember the sacrifice of Canadians who have served or died in wars up to the present day.
102.answer: To remember the sacrifice of Canadians who have served or died in wars up to the present day.

103.question: What is the name of the Governor General?

104.question: What is the name of the Prime Minister of Canada and his/her party?

105.question: What is the name of the Royal Anthem of Canada?

106.question: What is the role of the courts in Canada?
options: To guide people in our society.
To express values and beliefs of Canadians.

107.question: What is the role of the Opposition parties?
options: To oppose or try to improve government proposals.
To put forward bills to be passed.
107.answer: To oppose or try to improve government proposals.

108.question: What is the significance of the discovery of insulin by Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best?
options: Insulin is a hormone that permits you to eat anything you wish.
Insulin has saved 16 million lives worldwide.
Discovering insulin opened the doors to more discoveries.
Discovering insulin made Drs. Banting and Best famous.
108.answer: Insulin has saved 16 million lives worldwide.

109.question: What part of the Constitution legally protects the basic rights and freedoms of all Canadians?
options: The British Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
109.answer: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

110.question: What percentage of Aboriginal people are First Nations?

111.question: What should you do if you do not receive a voter information card telling you when and where to vote?
options: Call Elections Canada or visit their website.
111.answer: Call Elections Canada or visit their website.

112.question: What song is Canada’s national anthem?

114.question: What was the “Underground Railroad”?
options: An anti-slavery network that helped thousands of slaves escape the United States and settle in Canada
A railroad through the Rockies that was mainly through mountain tunnels
A network fur traders used to transport beaver pelts to the United States
The first underground subway tunnel in Toronto
114.answer: An anti-slavery network that helped thousands of slaves escape the United States and settle in Canada

115.question: What was the significance of June 6, 1944 invasion of Normandy?
options: It led to the establishment of the Juno Awards.
It liberated North Africa from Nazi occupation.
Canadians made a significant contribution to the defeat of Nazism and Fascism in Europe during the Second World War.
It resulted in the forcible relocation of Canadians of Japanese origin.
115.answer: Canadians made a significant contribution to the defeat of Nazism and Fascism in Europe during the Second World War.

116.question: What was the Women’s Suffrage Movement?
options: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote.
The effort by women to participate in military service.
An unsuccessful movement to get husbands to do housework.
The effort by women to be in Parliament.
116.answer: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote.

117.question: What will you promise when you take the Oath of Citizenship?
options: Pledge allegiance to the King, observe the laws of Canada and fulfil the duties of a Canadian.
Pledge to be faithful to the King.
Promise to observe the laws of Canada.
Fulfil duties as a Canadian citizen.
117.answer: Pledge allegiance to the King, observe the laws of Canada and fulfil the duties of a Canadian.

118.question: What year did Newfoundland and Labrador join Canada?

120.question: When asked, who must you tell how you voted in a federal election?

121.question: When did the British North America Act come into effect?

122.question: When did the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms become part of the Canadian Constitution?

123.question: When is Canada Day and what does it celebrate?
options: June 15 of each year to celebrate the anniversary of Confederation.
August 8th of each year to celebrate the joining of British Columbia to Confederation.
We celebrate the anniversary of Confederation July 1st of each year.
May 21st of each year to remember Queen Victoria.
123.answer: We celebrate the anniversary of Confederation July 1st of each year.

125.question: When must federal elections be held?
options: On the third Monday in October every four years following the most recent general election.
Whenever the Prime Minister calls the election.
When the MPs want a new Prime Minister.
125.answer: On the third Monday in October every four years following the most recent general election.

126.question: When you vote on election day, what do you do?
options: Go to the voting station, tell them who you are and mark your X.  Give the ballot back to the attendant.
Go to the voting station, remove 1 ballot and after marking your X deposit it in the ballot box.
Go to the voting station, take your voter\'s card with proof if identity, highlight your choice on the ballot and deposit it in the box.

Go to the voting station with your voter\'s card and ID, mark an X next to your chosen candidate, fold the ballot and present it to the poll officials who will tear off the ballot number and give you the ballot to deposit in the box
126.answer: Go to the voting station with your voter\'s card and ID, mark an X next to your chosen candidate, fold the ballot and present it to the poll officials who will tear off the ballot number and give you the ballot to deposit in the box

127.question: Where are the Great Lakes?
options: Between Ontario and the United States
127.answer: Between Ontario and the United States

128.question: Where are the Parliament Buildings located?

129.question: Where do most French-speaking Canadians live?

130.question: Where does Canada rank in the world’s largest countries?

131.question: Which Act granted, for the first time in Canada, legislative assemblies elected by the people?

132.question: Which animal is an official symbol of Canada?

133.question: Which country borders Canada on the south?

134.question: Which federal political party is in power?

135.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of Canada’s system of government?

136.question: Which of the following sentences best describes the War of 1812?
options: Napoleon's fleet was defeated by the Royal Navy in the war.
The USA became independent from the British Empire after the war.
The USA invaded Canada and was defeated, which ensured that Canada would remain independent of the United States.
Canada joined the United States after the war.
136.answer: The USA invaded Canada and was defeated, which ensured that Canada would remain independent of the United States.

137.question: Which of the following statements about residential schools is NOT true?
options: The federal government placed many Aboriginal children in residential schools to educate and assimilate them into mainstream Canadian culture.
The schools were poorly funded and inflicted hardship on the students.
The schools were welcomed by the Aboriginal people.
Aboriginal language and cultural practices were mostly prohibited.
137.answer: The schools were welcomed by the Aboriginal people.

138.question: Which party becomes the Official Opposition?
options: The party with the second most MPs.
The party receiving the least votes.
The party the Prime Minister selects.
138.answer: The party with the second most MPs.

139.question: Which party is the Official Opposition at the federal level?

140.question: Which port is the largest and busiest in Canada?

141.question: Which province has its own time zone?

142.question: Which province in Canada is the smallest in land size?

143.question: Which province is the main producer of pulp and paper and hydro-electricity?

144.question: Which province is the only officially bilingual province?

145.question: Which province was split into two at Confederation?

146.question: Which province was the first to grant voting rights to women?

147.question: Which provincial flag features the fleur-de-lys?

148.question: Which region covers more than one-third of Canada?

149.question: Which region is known as the industrial and manufacturing heartland of Canada?

150.question: Which region of Canada is known for both its fertile agricultural land and valuable energy resources?

151.question: Which three countries are signatories to NAFTA?
options: Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States.
Canada, the United States and Japan.
Canada, Mexico and the United States.
151.answer: Canada, Mexico and the United States.

152.question: Which was the last province to join Canada?

153.question: Who are the Aboriginal peoples of Canada?
options: The first European settlers to arrive in Canada
The descendents of the first Australian immigrants to Canada
The first people to live in Canada
153.answer: The first people to live in Canada

154.question: Who are the Acadians?
options: The descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.
English speaking refugees who settled in Louisiana.
154.answer: The descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.

155.question: Who are the founding peoples of Canada?

156.question: Who are the Métis?
options: The distinct aboriginal people of Atlantic Canada.
A people of mixed Inuit/First Nations ancestry most of whom live on the Prairies.
First Nations people speaking the Michif dialect.
A distinct people of mixed Aboriginal and European ancestry.
156.answer: A distinct people of mixed Aboriginal and European ancestry.

158.question: Who do Canadians vote for in a federal election?
options: The best speaker running in the election.
A candidate they want to represent them in Parliament.
All of the candidates in their electoral district.
158.answer: A candidate they want to represent them in Parliament.

159.question: Who do Members of Parliament represent?
options: All of the Canadians living in the north.
Only Canadians living in Central Canada.
Everyone who lives in his or her electoral district.
Canadians living in the province in which he/she was elected.
159.answer: Everyone who lives in his or her electoral district.

160.question: Who had played an important part in building the Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR)?

161.question: Who has the right to run as a candidate in federal elections?
options: A Canadian citizen who is 16 years old.
Any man who is at least 18 years old.
Any Canadian citizen who is at least 18 years old.
161.answer: Any Canadian citizen who is at least 18 years old.

162.question: Who has the right to vote in federal elections?
options: A Canadian citizen, 18 years or older, and on voters' list.
A Canadian citizen, 18 years or older and must work for the federal government.
A landed immigrant, 18 years old and a memberof the Canadian Forces.
A Canadian citizen, over 25 years and a member of the Canadian Forces.
162.answer: A Canadian citizen, 18 years or older, and on voters' list.

Immigrants to Canada in the 18th Century

178.question: Why is the battle of Vimy Ridge important?
options: It was a key position of the German line in Northern Spain.
Canadian Corps secured its reputation for valour and bravery.
It was the "hinge" of the German line as it protected the newly constructed Hindenburg line.
Once Canadians fought at Vimy they knew they would be heading home.
178.answer: Canadian Corps secured its reputation for valour and bravery.
